title.narrative: The Government and partners have strengthened capacities to develop, implement and monitor coordinated, evidence-based policies, strategies and plans for equitable, gender-responsive and sustainable access to basic WASH services.

description.narrative:
The issuance of the Philippine Approach to Sustainable Sanitation (PhATSS) policy guidelines by the Department of Health in November 2019 was a significant achievement. The policy provides a monitoring framework, institutional roles and responsibilities, and sanitation programmatic guidance for Local Government Units and other sector stakeholders to move communities from open defecation to sustainable and safely managed sanitation.
UNICEF has invested in strengthening engagement with the National Economic and Development Agency, responsible for the new Philippines Master Plan for Water Supply and Sanitation, which provided opportunities to lobby for equity-focused financing under the Unified Financing Framework. | Status:Constrained | As-of Date:07/02/2020

title.narrative: Availability of a costed plan in place to promote hygiene and handwashing in response to COVID-19 [COVID]

National strategy to eliminate open defecation available

baseline.value: Established (National strategy approved and adopted, but not regularly funded or reviewed), 2019 actual budget: P14m, 2018: Partial data on G1/ZOD only

actual.value: 2019:Although overall status cannot yet be considered fully upgraded to ‘championing', some progress has been made this year with (a) issuance of PhATSS policy (which operationalizes the existing NSSP, and reinforces the national ZODP); (b) DOH CO now requesting for periodic ZODP updates from ROs; (c) ef

title.narrative: Existence of functioning cluster coordination mechanism for water, sanitation and hygiene in humanitarian situations

baseline.value: National level: Initiating (Coordination mechanisms for humanitarian action exists and needs external support to co-lead the sector coordination role); 2018: No national policy on WASH cluster institutionalization at subnational level; 2018: Strategic plan in place, but no operational plan and gaps in costing

target.value: 2023:Championing (Coordination mechanism for humanitarian action exists and no UNICEF support required)

actual.value: 2019:Developed new WASH Cluster Strategic Plan 2019-2021 with vision for DOH leadership. Supported DOH in development of WASH in Emergencies policy, standards and technical guidelines – which would provide framework for institutionalising the cluster approach at national and subnational levels. DOH stil

title.narrative: Existence of functioning sector coordination mechanism for water, sanitation and hygiene

baseline.value: National: Initiating; Subnational: Weak (Gov't led coordination mechanism does not exist at subnational level and needs support to lead, co-lead or provide more than 50% resources); 2018: IACEH TWG existing ('initiating'); RIACEH Reg 8: established; RIACEH Reg 9: tbc

target.value: 2023:Championing by 2023 (Functioning government-led coordination mechanism exists at subnational levels and no UNICEF support required)

actual.value: 2019:National: Existing IACEH coordination mechanism continued in 2019, but WASH sub-group (led by DILG) was inactive. In parallel, NEDA began to hold more frequent meetings with WASH development partners to coordinate around the finalization of the new WSS Master Plan and Unified Financing Framework.
